The House met at 30.80 a.m., pursuant to the proclamation of His Excellency the Governor General. The CLKKK read the proclamation. OPENING OF THE PARLIAMENT. The USHER OF THE BLACK Ron, being announced, wa3 admitted, and delivered the message that the Deputies of the Governor General for the Opening of the Parliament desired the attendance orable members in the Senate chamber forthwith. Honourable members attended accordingly, and having returned, The DEPUTY authorized by the Governor General to administer the oath entered the chamber. The CLERK read the commission, under the Great Seal of the Commonwealth, authorizing the Right Honourable Sir George Edward Rich, a Justice 'of the High Court of Australia, to administer the oath, or affirmation, of allegiance to the King required by the Constitution to be taken or made by members of the House of Representatives. ELECTION OF SPEAKER.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: Unknown
text: ! That the honourable member for Darwin (Mr. Bell) do take the chair of this House as Speaker.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHINSON
Title: Unknown
text: -I second the motion. Questions resolved in the affirmative. Members of the House then calling Mr. Bell lo the Chair, he was taken out of his place by Mr Hawker and Mr. Hutchinson, and conducted to the Chair. Mr SPEAKER ELECT, standing on the upper step, said - I feel very deeply the honour which honourable members have conferred upon me by selecting me for the second time to preside over their deliberations. The majority of honourable members present have had experience of the manner in which I have discharged the duties of Speaker, and on that account I feel that the honour which they now do me is greater than that which they did me three years ago. The Standing Orders are the rules that have been laid down by this House for the guidance of honourable members in the conduct of its business. It is my function to interpret those rules, and to see that they are observed, so that the business of this chamber may be conducted smoothly. I cannot perfectly, or even satisfactorily, achieve that purpose unless I have the help of all honourable members. I am confident that I shall have that help, and that, with the co-operation of all, we shall do great credit to ourselves and make of this institution what we all hope it is regarded as being throughout the world. 1 thank honourable members sincerely.

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Title: Unknown
text: On behalf of members of the Government, and of ministerial members generally, 1 offer to you, Mr Speaker, very warm congratulations upon having been selected unanimously by this House to occupy the position that you previously filled with very great credit to yourself and benefit to the Parliament. Personally I am very glad indeed that one who has been so closely' associated with me has received that honour from this House, more particularly as, viewing the matter from perhaps an insular viewpoint, you, sir, are a fellow Tasmanian. I promise that you shall have the fullest co-operation of honourable members on this side of the House in the discharge of your duties. You have truly said that, however highly Qualified a Speaker may be, he cannot achieve real success nor-in your own words-satisfactoril y perform his duties, unless he has the co-operation of all honourable members. You will have that cooperation. I sincerely truaj that your experience during the life of this Parliament will give you cause for the greatest satisfaction, and that your health, which previously was not all that could be desired, will be the best that God has in His gift.

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Title: Unknown
text: Very , very sincerely, Mr Speaker, I offer to you on behalf of myself and of those who sit behind me, our warmest congratulations on your re-election as Speaker of this Parliament. We are confident that you will maintain the very highest traditions of your honourable office, and are quite certain that your appeal for the support of all honourable members will be responded to in the fullest possible way. I know that honourable gentlemen who sit on this side of the chamber will need no remonstrance to cause them to realise their duty to you, and to the office that vou hold. I make no reference to the Past, other than to express the hope that the head of the Government will set an oxumpie in that respect. The dignify of your office, sir, is a very important feature in the parliamentary system of English-speaking peoples, more particularly among the members of the self governing dominions which constitute the British Commonwealth of Nations. We believe in this system of representative government. We also believe that the Parliament must have a spokesman, that his office should be respected, and that the occupant of it should be regarded as entitled to a place among the most distinguished gentlemen of the country. We offer to you, sir, our best respects, and sincerely endorse the hope expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Lyons) that during the life of this Parliament you wall enjoy the best health it is possible for you to have.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: I sincerely thank the Prime Minister (Mr Lyons) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Curtin) for their congratulations upon my attainment to this high and honourable office, and for the very kind remarks that they have made concerning me personally. PRESENTATION TO GOVERNOR-GENERAL.

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Title: Unknown
text: I have ascertained that it will be the pleasure of His Excellency the Governor General to receive you, Mr. Speaker, in the Library of the Parliament at 2.45 p.m. this day.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: Prio r to my presentation to His Excellency the Governor General .the bells will be rung for five minutes so that those honourable members who so desire may accompany me to the Library, and there be presented to His Excellency.

Speaker: Unknown

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: I have to report, that, accompanied by honourable members, I proceeded to the Library of Parliament and presented myself to His Excellency the Governor General as the choice of the House, and that His Excellency was kind enough to congratulate-me on my election as Speaker. GOVERNOR-GENERAL'S The USHER OF THE BLACK ROD, being announced, was admitted, and delivered the message that His Excellency the Governor General desired the attendance of honourable members in the Senate chamber forthwith. Mr SPEAKER and honourable members attended accordingly, and returned, NA

text: Hon. G. J. B e l l ) I have received from His Excellency the Governor General a commission authorizing me to administer the oath, or affirmation, of allegiance to members of " the House. I now lay the commission on the table. MINISTERIAL CHANGES.

Title: LEADE R AN D DEPUTY LEADE R
text: I have to inform the House that *t have been appointed Leader, and the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Forde), Deputy Leader, of the Opposition. NA OF THE COUNTRY PARTY.

Speaker: Dr EARLE PAGE
Title: LEADE R AN D DEPUTY LEADE R
text: I desire to intimate to the House that I have been appointed leader, and the honourable member for Calare (Mr Thorby) deputy leader, of the Country party. NA (ACCEPTANCE) BILL 1937. Motion (by Mr LYONS) agreed toThat he have leave to bring in a hill for an act relating to the Territory for the Seat of Government. Bill brought up, and read a first time. NA SIR GRANVILLE RYRIE .

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Title: DEATH OF T HE HONORABLE
text: It is with deep regret that I refer to the death, on the 2nd October last, in Sydney, of Sir Granville Ryrie, a former member of this House. Born at Michelago, which is within comparatively short distance of the Federal Capital, on the 1st July, 1865, first entered Parliament in 1906 ber for Queanbeyan in the Legislative Assembly of New South "Wales. His the service in the Commonwealth Parliament Granville extended over a period of sixteen years, first as member for Nort h Sydney f r o 1911 to 1919, and later'as member for for Warringah from 1919 to 1927. As a appreciation young man he served in the South A f r i War, in which he was severely wounded. In recognition of his service, he was awarded the Queen's medal with four clasps. Shortly after the outbreak of the Great War in 1914, he proceeded overseas with the 2nd Ligh t Horse Brigade, and was subsequently appointed to the command of the Australian Imperial Force in Egypt with the rank of Major-General. He was honoured by H is Majesty the King on three occasions by the award the decorations of C.M.G., C.B., and KCMG . Shortly .after the termination of the war he attained ministerial office in the Hughes Ministry as Assistant Minister for Defence, and in 1927 he was appointed to succeed the Right Honourable Sir Joseph Cook as High Commissioner for places, the Commonwealth in London. Sir Granville Ryrie's record of public service, which I have briefly reviewed, is an inspiring one. He was a very sincere thereon. man, possessing an intense love for his native country. H is interests were many, but he was specially devoted to the pastoral industry with which he had been closely associated from boyhood. His comrades in the Australian I m perial Force pay tribute to capacity for leadership, and to his forceGeneral, f u l , but genial and likeable personality. Those associated with him in the ministerial and parliamentary spheres testify to his very capable service. He remembered by them as a loyal and trustLord worthy colleague. Sir Granville Ryrie rendered service to the Commonwealth in his capacity as High Commissioner in London, and in all his work he served Australia with distinction. He well merited the prominent position which is retained ifr. Li/mis. a of him - in the memories of the Australian people. To his widow and family he we desire to offer our sincere sympathy as memi n their loss. I move-h y leaveThat this House expresses its deep regret at death of Major-Gcneral the Honourable Sir de Laune Ryrie, KCMG., C.B., V.D., a former member of the New South Wales and Commonwealth Parliaments, Assistant Comm monwealth Minister, and High Commissioner Australia in London, places on record its of his distinguished public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to c an his widow and family in their bereavement.

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Title: DEATH OF T HE HONORABLE
text: I second the motion and unreservedly subscribe to the sentiments expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Lyons). The late Sir Granville Ryrie had a very long service, both in the public, and also the military, life of Australia, as the Prime Minister has said. H is very distinguished career was crowned by his appointment as " the representative of Australia in the important office of High Commissioner in of London. His very notable record indicated the possession of a great variety of gifts and qualifications. I pay tribute to the work he has done, and express very deep sympathy with his widow and family. Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their Motion (by Mr LYONS) agreed toThat Mr Speaker be requested to transmit to Lady Kyrie the foregoing resolution, together with a copy of the speeches delivered GOVERNOR - GENERA L. Speaker: Mr NOCK
Title: DEATH OF T HE HONORABLE
text: I move That the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prowse) he appointed Chairman of Committees of this House.

Speaker: Mr GREGORY
Title: DEATH OF T HE HONORABLE
text: I second the motion. Question resolved in the a f f i r m at i v e .

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Title: DEATH OF T HE HONORABLE
text: On behalf of honourable members on this side of the H o u se I tender Defence c o n g r at u l at i o ns to the honourable member  appointed h y this chamber on a vote w h i c h was, as in y o u r case, Mr Speaker, UIDIruinous, to the p o s it i o n of C h a i r m a n of Committees, w h i c h he has occupied for some time past. I assure him of the co-operation and l o y a l t y of honourable members in the c a r r y in g o ut of his i m p o r t a n t duties, and w is h him success in his occupancy of his p o s it i o n . If e e l sure that I speak for all h o n o r a b le members in of f e r in g the honourable member cong r at u l at i o n s , promise, of co-operation, and wishes that he may achieve success in the performance of his duties.

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Title: DEATH OF T HE HONORABLE
text: I expross to the honourable member for For on the honour that the House has done him in appointing him Chairman of Committees. I should like to feci assured that this appointment is not a consolation trophy bestowed on the honourable member. There are rumours that he was intended for a much more important office-on e on the Executive. I do not know what happened; all I know is that today ho litis been appointed Chairman of Committees. 1 assure the honourable member that honourable gentlemen on this side of the House will do their very utmost, consistent with their duty, to observe the dignity of the chamber, and to observe also the Standing Orders. I assure him also, that, whatever may have happened on a previous occasion, we shall not in any way recollect it, but I offer- I hope without impertinence-the suggestion that he himself certainly should not forget it.  acknowledge with thanks the confidence that this House has again reposed in me, and to thank the Right Honourable the Prime Minister (Mr. Lyons) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Curtin) for the complimentary remarks they made concerning myself. I can assure the Leader of the Opposition that I shall not forget too readily the occasion to which he was kind enough to refer. I should like to say how completely I concur with the observations which you, Mr Speaker, were good enough to make to the chamber on your election earlier today. I endorse them nil, and am thankful for the co-operation promised by the Leader of the Opposition on behalf of the Opposition. I shall do my very best to be fair, and to comply with the Standing Orders which are set for the guidance of every honourable member as well as that of the Speaker and the Chairman of Committees. HOUR OF MEETING. Motion (hy Mr LYONS) agreed toThat the House, at its rising, adjourn until tomorrow at 2.30 p.m. House adjourned at 3.37 p.m.
